CHIC AFFAIRS AND PUBLIC DISCUSSION: Harley and Probst reviewed the past
connection with the consultants in this area, Harold Lasswell and Charles
E. Herriam. Lasswell had presented his suggestion for a series of clarify¬
ing discussion programs out of a Washington, D.C. headquarters last September
At the October 30 meeting of the committee in Biloxi, authorization was given
to Harley to investigate the idea. At the December 8-9 meetings in New York,
committee members expressed doubt about the relationship between a top-name
civic broadcasting council membership and the Lowell Institute program pro¬
jects of the NAEB.
Lasswell and Merriam suggested many names for this civic broadcasting council
Harley had worked on the approach of asking Judge Learned Hand to be its
chairman (see minutes of December 8-9 meetings and January 6-7 meetings for
details). At the January Ames, Iowa, meeting, on the basis of the informa¬
tion Harley had assembled, he wa3 instructed to go ahead and set up the
Washington operation. At this time, Robert Hudson, consultant to the FAE,
privately told Harley to go slow on this matter until after the March meet¬
ing of the FAE. Apparently the FAE was thinking of setting up a committee
similar to the one suggested by Lasswell and Merriam. Harley reported that
Lasswell feels that since such a long time has elapsed batmen the original
suggestion and the present, and because the NAEB has failed to implement it,
and since Lasswell is devoted to seeing his idea fully developed as a contri¬
bution to democracy through better public information and opinion, Lasswell
has said that he wishes to withdraw his suggestion as one for the NAEB to
implement. Harley stated that we had no alternative but to accept Mr. Lass-
well’s decision.
Probst stated that he felt we had missed a big bet in our failure in this
area. Lasswell is one of the smartest political scientists in the country,
and he gave us a million dollar idea. Our committee did not give Harley
authority enough to move fast enough to do something about it. Siegel dis¬
agreed, saying that the idea was not definite enough and that you could not
expect any committee to buy a pig in a poke. Hull moved that the Harley-
Probst reports and outlines on the Lasswell suggestion be made a part of our
annual report, and that it be made clear that one of the reasons we failed
to accomplish it was because of the advice from the FAE liaison person to
go slow.
Lasswell may or may not continue to be our consultant in this area; Harley
is seeing him in a few days. In the meantime, Mr. Merriam has suffered a
very serious illness. Harley will discuss with Merriam’s assistant the
return of the $5,000.00 minus whatever incidental expenditures have been
made from this sum. It is estimated that about $4,600.00 would be returned.
